Explanation:
The analyzed file appears to belong to the "DownloadAdmin" malware family, with indications of potentially unwanted program (PUP) behaviors. Various antivirus engines have flagged this file as malicious, including DrWeb identifying it as "Trojan.Vittalia.2469" and TrendMicro characterizing it as "PUA_DOWNADMIN.SM". The file has been submitted three times for analysis, reflecting its potential widespread impact or distribution attempts. While specific indicators of compromise (IOCs) such as URLs, IPs, or domains aren't directly provided, several engines report it as an adware or downloader, suggesting that it could engage in further downloading of malware or ads.

The file's signature includes a "Code Signing" certificate, but its reputation remains neutral, possibly due to the expired validity of the certificate or misuse by malicious actors. Sandbox analysis should focus on observing any network communication attempts or persistence mechanisms. Detection statistics exhibit 62 malicious and 10 undetected instances among antivirus scans, supporting the risk categorization. Key behaviors include downloading additional content and potentially exhibiting adware-like traits. As a countermeasure, it is advisable to utilize endpoint protection with real-time scanning turned on, alongside deploying network monitoring to detect any unusual traffic patterns. Mitigation strategies should also involve educating users on safe download practices and ensuring executions of known software only from trusted sources.
